rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A petrographical study of specimens of rocks and ores from the Sullivan Mine, Kimberley, B.C.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The Sullivan mine was discovered by Patrick Sullivan and three associates in 1895, and during the next year was bonded to Col. Redpath and Judge Turner of Spokane, Washington. The Sullivan Group Mining Company of Spokane was later formed to take over the property, and a smelter, which was designed to treat ore from the mine, was completed in 1903 at Marysville, B.C. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geological Sciences

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: An investigation of the strength functions of Nova Scotia mine timbers
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: During the summer of 1914 arrangements were completed between the Forestry Branch of the Department of the Interior, Canada, and the Mining Department of McGill University, whereby an investigation into the consumption of timber in Nova Scotia, with particular reference to timber used in the mining operations of that province, was undertaken. Outlines of the work to be covered were prepared and a representative was commissioned to obtain the required information. One important phase of the investigation as outlined was the determination of the strength functions of the various species of timber suitable for mining purposes. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Engineering

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The effect of frost on the germination of corn
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The value of corn as a cereal crop in the warmer portions of North America has long been recognized, but its dependability in the cooler regions of the continent depends to a large extent upon the variety or strain grovm. In localities where temperature is the limiting factor there exists the ever present danger of frost injury to that which is being matured for seed, and the larger part of Canada, outside of a portion of south-western Ontario, is included in this area.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Plants -- Frost resistance
Agronomy
Corn
Germination

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The Montessori principles
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Whatever the final judgment on the work of Dr. Maria Montessori of Rome, it is true to say that through her a renaissance has taken place in the interest of educationists and of parents in the welfare both intellectual and physical of young children. Dr. Montessori1s system, that is at present arousing such wide-spread interest, is based on knowledge rather than intuition. It is the result of her extraordinary personality and womanly sympathy combined with her scientific training and broad social outlook. Her intensive and long continued study of educational problems, together with her varied experience as a teacher and educational leader has fitted her admirably to undertake the task of reconstructing educational methods. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Education

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: INJECTION OF FOREIGN PARTICLES INTO THE BLOOD STREAM
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The experiments to be described in the following thesis were undertaken at the suggestion of Professor John Tait. He had found (1918) that thigmocytic blood cells i.e. cells which are readily pulled out by capillary attraction on water wetable surfaces, are highly phagocytic. Mammalian blood platelets belong to the category of thigmocytes, and Tait had found that they may ingest small particles of carmine. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physiology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Molecular weight at low temperatures
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The object of this work was to make a careful study of several compounds formed with liquid hydrogen bromide in order, if possible, to learn something of their molecular complexity.The determinations were made in duplicate and at a greater concentration than heretofore. It has been shown (1) that organic substances containing oxygen, when dissolved in liquified hydrobromic acid, unite with the solvent forming definite salts melting far above the M.P of either constituent. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The production of damped electric waves
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The production of damped electric waves, using as a source of energy a low potential alternating current; the grouping of some to form impulses of the same order as those of audible notes: [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: ElectricalEngineering

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The elementary theory of sets of points, with an introductory essay on irrational numbers
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: It is quite generally known that arithmetic had its beginning in the counting of groups of things, such as trees and herds of cattle; but it is not nearly so widely understood why the number ten should have been chosen as the basal unit of our initial system of enumeration, the decimal system, rather than any other number. When one considers that counting would naturally take the form of telling off the objects of a group on the fingers of both hands, it is easy to understand how the positive whole numbers were constructed on the decimal system. Clearly the decimal system of notation is not the only one that could be invented. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mathematics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: L'orient musulman dans la littérature française au XVIIle et XIXe siècles
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Dans une étude aussi brève a'un sujet si vaste, l'impossibilité de discuter, de façon adéquate, tous les ouvrages méritoires est évidente, et nos portraits des auteurs même les plus illustres ne seront que des miniatures. Je ne tâcherai qu'à appuyer sur les ouvrages et les genres d'une importance notoire. Le théâtre oriental et les voyages professionnels perdent leur prestige après le XVIIIe siècle. D'autre part la poésie orientale et le tourisme ne commencemt à avoir une existence vigoureuse qu' au XIXe siècle. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: French

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The relation between the chemical constitution of organic liquids and their ability to swell rubber
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Previous experimenters have nearly all rendered their results valueless for purposes of independent comparison by employing vulcanised or sheet rubber of unspecified, if not unknown, history and composition, such as "black rubber tubing", etc., and in most cases have assumed the swelling to reach a maximum within twenty-four hours. This is an obvious fallacy in the light of the following results. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Electric power transmission by alternating current at high voltage
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The purpose of an electric transmission line is to transmit electric power from one place to another; and the line is so designed and constructed as to fulfil its particular purpose in the best and most economical manner. There are two systems in common use today: the direct current system and the alternating-current single-phase or three phase system, for general transmission. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Electrical Engineering

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The purification of pepsin and the determination of the chemical constitution and physical characters of the preparations obtained
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: It is evident that the preparation of pure pepsin must present very great difficulty to the investigator, for proteins occur with it in the media from which it must be prepared, and these, in traces, may remain with it when isolated. It is generally believed that its mode of action on proteins is through mass action promoted by its adsorption on the substrate. It is therefore probable that in ordinary solutions of it most of the pepsin is present in such association with the proteins and these consequently will tend to be precipitated with it. The great ease with which it is inactivated by heat, alkali, acid solutions of moderate concentration, and various organic and inorganic substances, greatly enhances these difficulties. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Metal losses in copper slags
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Mr. Heywood, relating his experience at the Ducktown Sulphur, Copper and Iron Company's smelter, showed graphically the effect of variations in the composition of the slag and in the grade of matte on the percentage of copper lost. He plotted the copper content of 2590 slags, representing the average of two furnaces over a period of two and a half years, against the copper content of the matte for curves [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Metallurgical Engineering

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Lord Carteret and the Hanoverian policy of the Georges
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: During the first half of the eighteenth Century, England was ruled by two Kings who by their speech, appearance and habits betrayed the fact that they were foreigners; and whose ideas and way of thinking all too plainly pointed at the fact of a German upbringing. Add to this that they possessed dominions on the Continent, which they ruled as arbitrary sovereigns, and for which they showed a marked partiality, and the difficulties, inherent in any such situation are immeasureably increased. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: History

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Report on the sewage disposal problem in Montreal
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: On account of the numerous complaints which have been received by the Board of Health of the Province of Quebec as to the existence of nuisances due to the discharge of crude sewage in the neighborhood of certain docks in the City of Montreal, it appears possible that the Board may take steps to conpel the city to treat its sewage, at least to some extent, before admitting it to the st. Lawrence. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Sanitary Engineering

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A determination of the coefficient of expansion of mercury at low temperatures
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In 1817 Dulong and Petit made a measurement of the absolute expansion of mercuxy from 0°C to 300°C using the method of equilibrating columns. This method is based on the principlethat if two columns of a U-tube containing a liquid are under the same conditions of pressuxe but at different temperatures then the density of the liquid in the columns will be inversely proportional to the heights. By this method no correction is necessary for the expansion of the containing vessel. One column was enclosed in an ice mixture and the other was encased in an oil bath heated by a furnace. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Problems in immunity with special reference to the Wassermann reaction
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The great simplicity of technic, the economy of material in the test and the fact that it could be used by any general practitioner seemed to indicate that [the Hermann-Perutz reaction] would supplant the Wassermann reaction. But it was soon discovered that the newly proposed test was not as sensitive as the Wassermann reaction, and that a considerable number of sera reacting negatively with the Wassermann reaction gave positive results with the Hermann-Perutz. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physiology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The significance of a law of nature in modern science
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The aim of this essay has been to present, in its most general and salient features, the origin and development of the proposed theme. In many cases authorities have been let speak for themselves; and although in quoting, the actual wording has often been modified for the sake of simplicity, clearness and continuity, the references have been given, so that the reader can easily refer to the originals. The writer has no wish to claim undue originality in the treatment of the problem, or in the views presented; and the work is offered as a study of a purely introductory and preliminary nature. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Philosophy

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Resonance radiations
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Generally when light is absorbed by a body its energy becomes transformed into heat energy. As heat energy is usually attributed to molecular motion by physicists of the present day, we may say that absorbed light energy is usually transformed into molecular energy. The molecular condition of the substance has much to do with the transformation of energy, and hence in certain cases absorbed light gives rise to new light or heat waves. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Les principes de Moliere sur I'education des femmes
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Personne n'ignore les services inestimables rendus par Molière à la Comédie. Avant lui, les dramaturges se croyaient obligés de traiter de "grands sujets".(1) Le public d'ailleurs, voulait une intrigue forte et des personnages extraordinaires. Par la puissance de son génie créateur, Molière a su opposer au système dramatique de ses prédécesseurs, une peinture fidèle de la vie de tous les jours. Se moquant des theoriciens, et laissant de côté les conventions acceptées par ses contemporains, il proclama hautement que la grande règle au théâtre, est de plaire. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: French

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The variation in varieties and mixtures of cereal and forage crops with respect to border effect in comparative crop tests
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: During recent years experimentalists have been giving more and more attention to "Methods of experimentation". Far too great a variety of methods have been employed in an endeavour to obtain accurate results for the problem under consideration, perhaps in no other class of experimental work has the complexity of methods in vogue been more conspicuous than in that conducted by the agronomist.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Grain
Agronomy
Forage plants

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies concerning bean anthracnose
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Bean anthracnose is of constant seasonal ocurrence in Quebec and the Maritimes and of considerable economic importance. It was therefore thought worth while to study the disease generally. This leads to a consideration of disease-resistant varieties and in view of the importance of physiological specialization as shown by the work of Barrus, Burkholder and Leach it was desirable that work be done to determine what physiological species of C. lindemuthianum, if any, occur in Eastern Canada. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Plant Pathology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The discharge through helium and hydrogen & the measurement of the dielectric constant
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Under suitable conditions of pressure and current density the positive column shews alternations of dark and bright spaces, the discharge under these conditions being termed striated. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The relation of Kidney activity in Diabetes Insipidus to the Theories of urine excretion
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The problem of kidney activity in diabetes insipidus in its relation to the theories of urine excretion is being approached first, by representing the history of diabetes insipidus; secondly, by discussing the history of the theories of kidney activity in urine excretion; thirdly, by a careful examination of the urine voided by the diabetic on six different days. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Urination
Biochemistry
Diabetes
Kidneys

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A study of the colloidal behaviour of rubber
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Modern colloidal chemistry is the result of the development of Graham's (1) epoch-making experiments which led to his classification of matter into the crystalloidal and colloidal states. In the development, however, Graham's classification has not been retained. The large number of facts that have been discovered since 1861 indicates that a sharp line can scarcely be drawn between the two domains. Probably the best classification is cde to Freundlich (2). This author used the term lyophobe to represent colloids, which when taken in bulk had no affinity for the dispersion medium, while lyophile was the term used to designate a colloid which when taken in bulk was peptized by the dispersion medium. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry
